questions.text: What is a key component of the 'freemium' business model?
options: All features are always free
Basic service is free, premium features require payment
First month free, then mandatory payment
Free for individuals, paid for businesses only
questions.explanation: The freemium model offers a basic version of the product for free to attract users, while charging for premium features, advanced functionality, or additional services. This lowers barriers to entry while creating revenue from engaged users.

questions.text: What does 'network effects' mean in business?
options: Having good internet connectivity
The product becomes more valuable as more people use it
Marketing through professional networks
Connecting multiple businesses together
questions.explanation: Network effects occur when a product or service becomes more valuable as more people use it. Examples include social media platforms, marketplaces, and communication tools - each new user increases the value for all existing users.

questions.text: What is the primary goal of a 'pivot' in business?
options: To change the company name
To fire underperforming employees
To change strategy based on market feedback
To move to a new office location
questions.explanation: A pivot is a strategic change in business direction based on what you've learned from the market. It might involve changing your target customer, value proposition, or product features while leveraging your existing assets and knowledge.

options: The time a customer stays with your company
The total revenue a customer generates over their entire relationship with your business
The average age of your customers
The number of purchases a customer makes per year
questions.explanation: Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) is the total revenue you can expect from a single customer account throughout their relationship with your business. It's crucial for determining how much you can spend on customer acquisition.

questions.text: What is the 'razor and blades' business model?
options: Selling expensive razors with cheap blades
Selling a low-margin or loss-leader product to drive sales of high-margin complementary products
A subscription service for shaving supplies
Competing on price by undercutting competitors
questions.explanation: The 'razor and blades' model involves selling a primary product cheaply (or even at a loss) to drive recurring sales of complementary consumables at higher margins. Examples include printers and ink cartridges, or gaming consoles and games.
